text:
No it won't lose authority. But the specific page will have built it's own authority already (i.e. links from other sites). Whereas a new post won't have any specific page authority as nobody links to it.

But for the long wrong, don't worry about it.

elements.text:

text: Got it. Thank you Dom for taking your time out and answering the question.

elements.text: Got it. Thank you Dom for taking your time out and answering the question.

text:
Hi Kelsey,


This is a great question and the answer is multi-layered. The correct answer is that your posting schedule should not be determined by anything search engine related. Essentially, if you do not have a reason to be posting frequently then you should probably not need to post frequently.

If someone is telling you to post frequently because it has “search advantages” it is probably just an upsell.

Posting frequency, at least, in my opinion is largely a myth. There are no huge tangible benefits from posting regularly.

If you update a page frequently Google will learn that the page you are updating changes frequently and will crawl that page more often. For you it sounds like you probably have a parent blog page that links to your various posts. In your case, the “benefit” would be that Google Bot crawls your blog page more frequently. Is that beneficial? And should you be posting a bunch of posts just so Google crawls your blog page more often? Probably not.

With that said, Google likes “consistency.” However, that does not mean “post frequently and aggressively” You can read more about consistency <https://www.seroundtable.com/google-seo-lives-dies-with-consistency-31319.html#:~:text=Google's%20John%20Mueller%20reiterated%20on,SEO%20lives%20%26%20dies%20with%20consistency.|here>.


With that said however, if you have a sound content plan that is designed to capture traffic and you are not just arbitrarily putting out blog posts because it is “good for SEO”, you should post them as fast as you can. It takes pages time to accumulate ranking signals, so, the faster you get them out the faster they can begin to accumulate ranking signals. Hope this helps!

attachments.fallback: seroundtable.com: John Mueller Of Google: SEO Lives & Dies With Consistency
attachments.text: Google's John Mueller reiterated on Twitter that consistency is the number one piece of SEO advice. He said last night on Twitter that
attachments.title: John Mueller Of Google: SEO Lives & Dies With Consistency

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> well this is quite an endorsement

elements.text: well this is quite an endorsement

text:
Aleyda Solis is brilliant, hands down. She's also created some really valuable learning paths for SEO and puts out SEOFOMO, a top-notch weekly newsletter and corresponding Twitter Spaces chat.
Barry Schwartz, editor at Search Engine Land, founder of Search Engine Roundtable, and host of Search Marketing Expo, is a must-follow. He writes a bajillion articles a day -- some will likely be beyond the scope you're looking for, but he engages with a lot of people in the space + has a strong relationship with the guys at Google, so he can definitely help keep you up to date and add more SEO info into your feed.
Dan Shure is a smart follow, too. He offers more info directly in tweets vs newsletter/blogs/etc.
If I were jumping into this industry anew, that's where I'd start.

elements.text:

He writes a bajillion articles a day -- some will likely be beyond the scope you're looking for, but he engages with a lot of people in the space + has a strong relationship with the guys at Google, so he can definitely help keep you up to date and add more SEO info into your feed.
Dan Shure is a smart follow, too. He offers more info directly in tweets vs newsletter/blogs/etc.
If I were jumping into this industry anew, that's where I'd start.

Someone was just promoting this service in another channel. Was wondering if anyone has used this before and if it's legit.
<https://www.rockethub.com/deal/link-sourcery>

attachments.text: Scale your earned media, domain authority, credibility, and traffic by identifying the best link opportunities, responding quicker, and efficiently managing your link building efforts.
attachments.title: Link Sourcery - RocketHub

elements.text: Someone was just promoting this service in another channel. Was wondering if anyone has used this before and if it's legit.

text: I have, and I like it pretty well! It's basically just a streamlined workflow for using HARO where you don't have to just look through 3 emails every day and can respond through the app. I like it, although I don't know for sure how much I'd pay for it. I'm pretty sure I'm on a free plan.
